hints.label: rmk-k-uniformity-mechanism-cinf
hints.title: k-Uniformity Mechanism
hints.content:
406: :label: rmk-k-uniformity-mechanism-cinf
407: 
408: The k-uniformity proven in C³ ([13_geometric_gas_c3_regularity.md](13_geometric_gas_c3_regularity.md) § 5.2, Lemmas 5.2-5.3) and C⁴ ([14_geometric_gas_c4_regularity.md](14_geometric_gas_c4_regularity.md) § 5, Lemmas 5.1-5.2) relies on the telescoping identity:
409: 
410: $$
411: \sum_{j \in A_k} \nabla^m w_{ij}(\rho) = 0 \quad \text{for all } m \geq 1
412: $$
413: 
414: This follows from differentiating ∑_j w_ij = 1 identically. The consequence is that sums like ∑_j ∇^m w_ij · d(x_j) can be rewritten as **centered sums**:
415: 
416: $$
417: \sum_j \nabla^m w_{ij} \cdot d(x_j) = \sum_j \nabla^m w_{ij} \cdot (d(x_j) - \mu_\rho)
418: $$
419: 
420: Since |d(x_j) - μ_ρ| ≤ diam(d) is uniformly bounded (X is compact), the sum scales as O(||∇^m w_ij||), not O(k · ||∇^m w_ij||). This prevents linear growth in k and ensures k-uniformity.
